messages.content: Hey everybody, it's really snowy out there. I gotta get out the door soon, but I wanted to share some incredible news with you that we just got for the second year running. The Ontario NDP closed the year with more donors than Doug Ford's Conservatives and the Ontario Liberals combined. Combined. In 2025, we actually raised $7.9 million from over 106,000 contributions. That's huge. Okay, nearly 80% of our contributions were under $100. And so what that means is that working people, regular people all across this province have been chipping in what they can and that is who's powering this. That's who New Democrats answer to. So I wanted to say this to everybody who's donated this year, thank you. Everything we've accomplished is thanks to you and everything that we can accomplish is thanks to you. We are building something here. real momentum and it's on me, it's on me to keep earning that trust every single day and I know it. Look, if you voted conservative in the last election, if you voted liberal, if you voted green or maybe, look, you didn't vote at all, I want you to take a look at our movement and I want you to be a part of it because we can make life more affordable. Absolutely. We can end the culture of corruption that is just plaguing our politics here. And we can. Absolutely. defeat Doug Ford in the next election and we can elect an Ontario NDP government.

# Classification: LEAN LEFT

## Summary
This post strongly aligns with progressive politics through its emphasis on grassroots fundraising from working people, critique of establishment "corruption," and promises to make life affordable while defeating the conservative incumbent. The messaging positions the NDP as a people-powered movement against entrenched political and economic interests.

## Evidence
- **Small-donor emphasis**: 80% of contributions under $100 frames the party as powered by "working people, regular people" rather than wealthy interests—a classic progressive populist appeal
- **Anti-corruption framing**: Criticism of a "culture of corruption plaguing our politics" challenges institutional trust and establishment parties from a left-progressive position
- **Policy focus**: Promises to "make life more affordable" and defeat Doug Ford signal left-leaning economic interventionism and opposition to conservative governance
- **Movement language**: Repeated use of "our movement" and appeals to voters across the spectrum emphasize coalition-building typical of progressive political strategy
